8.60.text:
Earlier this month three US scientists deployed
satellite tracking tags to nine humpback whales

13.01.text:
on the waters off Rarotonga with the aim of
gathering vital information about behaviour

18.00.text:
and migration patterns of these endangered
mammals.

20.36.text:
This is only the second time in history tracking
tags have been deployed on humpback whales

28.35.text:
The scientists, University of Canterbury lecturer
Dr. Travis Horton, Director of Cetacean Research

29.39.text:
and Conservation Nan Howser, and the National
Oceans and Atmospheric Administration's Alex

38.62.text:
Ceverny went to Rarotonga earlier this month
deploying the tags.

43.72.text:
Today I'm joined by one of the scientists,
Dr Travis Horton.

48.39.text: It's a pleasure to have you here

49.39.text: It's great to be here Jamiela

50.43.text:
Can you start be giving us an overview of
how the tagging went in Rarotonga and why

57.19.text: It's a, it was a tremendous success.

58.33.text:
We actually deployed more tags than we went
in with, uh we we actually went in with the

63.79.text:
research campaign with seven tags in hand
and the kind donations from people in Rarotonga

69.81.text:
and across the world in the conservation community
allowed us ten tags in total and we were able

73.90.text:
to deploy nine of them and we've got seven
migrating whales right now.

79.77.text:
So how did you become involved in this project,
you know, when, when did you become interested

85.77.text: yeah that's actuallyy, that's a great question.

87.62.text:
Because I'm actually a geologist and you might
"Wow, this guy's lost the plot, he's a geologist

92.90.text:
studying whales" but the connection there
is modern science is really making advances

99.74.text:
in the space in between in the traditional
disciplines so when I Iearned that whales

105.36.text:
and other animals might be using the magnetic
field to orientate I thought Hey, rocks give

111.40.text:
a magnetic field, particularly rocks associated
with Pacific Islands, the basalts and things

116.57.text:
that make up Hawaii and they also make up
Cook Islands so by using my knowledge as a

121.58.text:
geologist about magnetic field and magnetic
field properties and looking at how animals

127.01.text:
move through magnetic fields, we hope to gain
better understanding of how they're navigating,

132.91.text:
ok, so how did you end up becoming connected
with this particular whale tracking project?

138.44.text:
Yeah, so it was through the internet, back
in 2007 Nan, Nan Howser, the Director of the

143.77.text:
Whale Center there in the Cook Island, she
had seven tags that were getting updated every

147.80.text:
day on the internet and it was funded by Greenpeace
and it was a thing called the Great Whale

151.69.text:
Trail, you can still go see it online, and
I was watching the whales every day seeing

157.04.text:
what they were doing and it was also looking
at the magnetic fields that they were moving

160.64.text:
through so not just looking at Lat and Long
space but actually looking at the magnetic

164.26.text:
field and I was seeing patterns so that, that
really that kind of inspired me to contact

171.05.text:
Nan and she thought, Yeah, let's do this,
this is awesome, let's look at the whale movements

176.65.text:
from a geologist's perspective and that led
to a collaboration with NOAA and that led

181.15.text:
to a collaboration with the institute de acqua
lee in Brazil and it's just become this really

185.72.text:
international research team over the last
seven years.

188.79.text:
Totally, totally, so you deployed, um, nine
tracking tags in total, congratulations, can

195.47.text:
you explain what data you hope to glean from
this project and how it would help your understanding

202.23.text:
Yes, so we got the nine tags out and it's
really relevant to conservation, it's relevant

208.58.text:
to science, it's actually relevant to technilogical
innovation and it's also relevant to our own

213.78.text:
human migrations, so the data actually can
be applied and used through a number of different

221.73.text:
So the conservation side, these whales are
endangered, they're one of the two endangered

225.38.text:
humpback whale populations on the planet and
we've just don't know where they go, so if

229.56.text:
we want to protect them in the oceans and
develop marine protection areas that's something

234.09.text:
that we need to know what area to protect
so finding out where they go allows us to

239.87.text:
On the science side, we don't know how they
do it.

242.45.text:
How they are navigating across expanses of
open ocean, basically it's just a sea of blue

247.29.text:
and yet they can find Rarotonga again next
year.

250.68.text:
So how are they doing that is kind of our
key science question on the technological

254.74.text:
innovation there's a major push from the engineering
community to try to use animal navigation

263.11.text:
techniques and apply those techniques to drone
technology and gps technology, we're trying

270.68.text:
to figure out ways to better orientate across
the planet, and we're looking at animals to

275.88.text:
do that, that's the engineering innovation
side and on the human side one of the classic

282.03.text:
questions about New Zealand and this beautiful
place we're at right now come here, the last

288.42.text:
piece of continental crust that was settled
by humans, so the ancestors to Maori they

293.74.text:
arrived in New Zealand roughly 700 years ago
and the Maori oral traditions tells us that

299.01.text:
perhaps that the pikea, the humpback whale
guided if not guarded the waka on their way

305.37.text:
from Hawaiiki to Aotearoa New Zealand so what
we're actually seeing in the whale movements

309.95.text:
is they're literally island hopping, they're
I think you actually mentioned that in your

315.31.text:
it's so neat, the data is telling, it's showing
us the whales are basically going in straight

319.72.text:
lines from one island to the next to the next
to the next we don't know if they come to

322.97.text:
New Zealand yet, but we hoping that the transmitters
will last long enough to take them all the

326.89.text:
way down here
So on that note, can you tell us more about

333.67.text:
the tags, how long they last
yup

334.87.text:
and any other technical information about
them

335.87.text:
The, the biggest thing to say about the tags
is they are a cutting edge technology we couldn't

340.77.text:
do these kinds of things ten years ago well
fifteen years ago they link in with satellites

347.30.text:
they give us sub-kilometre even to potentially
metre scale resolutions so they're really

351.37.text:
a amazing technological innovation they communicate
with satellites there are six different satellites

356.35.text:
that they're talking with they're sending
signals to and yeah the tagging technology

363.72.text:
itself is a really technologically inspiring
thing in it's own right

369.45.text:
and you mentioned before ah, it's only looking
to get better and better, with the tags

376.64.text:
yeah, so you asked about the longevity of
the tags, that was one of the key things that

379.74.text:
has improved over the years, over the last
ten years.

382.10.text:
Previously we, we'd expects a tag to get four
to eight weeks perhaps, when Nan tagged whales

388.49.text:
in 2007 off Rarotonga they lasted about six
weeks, now days the average that one of these

395.11.text:
particular types of tags will last and actually
send data is about three months and ninety

399.74.text:
days kind of range so twelve weeks we've effectively
doubled the average length of time and we

404.86.text:
actually had one tag from Alex's work in Brazil
that stayed on a whale for three hundred and

410.25.text:
fiftenn days and it's the only tag that captures
both the southward and the northward migration

416.11.text:
of a humpback whale, it's absolutely unique
data

418.89.text:
awesome, so from the moment you launched the
tags you are able to track the humpback's

425.95.text:
location, has there been anything so far that
surprises you a bout their movements?

431.09.text:
Things that have surprised me, there are several
ah, one of them is they're moving in straight

435.70.text:
lines that surprises me in that it's hard
to do, the ocean is moving yet they are able

442.63.text:
to maintain constant courses, they can move
in a straight line that's one of them, the

446.35.text:
other is moving with constant speeds now that's
also really interesting in that the ocean

451.19.text:
might be pushing from behind a little bit
or in their face a little bit giving a head

456.91.text:
current so the fact that they're able to maintain
s speed is suggesting that they have some

461.22.text:
kind of temporal time keeping thing
the biggest insight that we gained from this

466.41.text:
year's data are these movements between the
islands the fact that they are taking directional

472.00.text:
constant speed movements from Rarotonga to
Atiu, from Rarotonga to American Samoa from

479.08.text:
Rarotonga to Niue, these are completely unprecedented
insights

483.02.text:
They know where they are going
They might have a memory, they might be just

487.33.text:
using tracks through the magnetic field they
might be using gravitational anomalies associated

491.80.text:
with the rocks they're doing something that
allows really precise navigation

495.70.text:
awesome
um, so there's quite a considerable amount

499.79.text:
of danger involved in actually tagging these
whales, um, you had to get within a certain

505.24.text:
distance and ensure you had a clear shot,
can you describe to us what that was like?

510.77.text:
Yeah, it, I'd never done anything like that
before in my life, it was absolutely an awe

519.53.text:
We tried to leave the whales as alone as possible,
so we're not always right up next to them

525.24.text:
but when we've patterned the surfacing rate
and we can anticipate when and where the whales

531.87.text:
will rise up, we'll put ourselves in a position
for us to deploy a tag safely, we kind of

537.94.text: zip in, deploy the tag and zip back out again.

541.34.text:
That;s where the danger part comes in, there's
a relatively rpaid movement in those last

547.62.text:
twenty metres or so to get the boat in a position
to safelty deploy, so you're not hurting the

552.23.text:
whale, deploying the tag, but at the same
time, you're not a hundred percent sure where

555.78.text:
the whale's going to be so there's potential
for an interaction between the whale and the

560.60.text:
boat, we've never ever had any in Rarotonga,
there is one example from the Arctic where

564.82.text:
that sort of interaction did happen, nobody
got hurt, the whale wasn't hurt but there

569.01.text:
is that element of danger every time you're
doing it, it's really, you get up on the edge

574.03.text:
of your seat in the boat, it's, it's anxious,
so truly exciting and inspiring at the saem

582.20.text:
So with the tags, um, does the whale, does
the whale feel it, ah, when you are launching

590.93.text:
Absolutely, there's no, we're all about doing
open and transparent with this, we're bsically

595.79.text:
putting the equivalent of a eariring post
into the skin in the small of their back,

602.37.text:
that would be the analogy to a human, if you
scale the things up and down, so yeah, same,

608.78.text:
same as we feel earrings getting inserted
in our ears, or elsewhere in your body, um,

614.12.text:
the whales certainly feel it, now one of the
things that we do is we monitor the whale's

618.35.text:
behaviour before we deply the tag and we monitor
the whales behaviour after we deploy the tags

623.43.text:
and one of the things that that 've observed,
is yeah, some whales might flick their tail

627.93.text:
a little bit, um, show that yep, I felt that,
um, other ones, no response at all, um, you

635.96.text:
don't see any obvious physical response so
we, the following of the whales for about

642.99.text:
forty minutes to at least an hour or as long
as we can, they're doing exactly the same

647.19.text:
things afterwards that they were doing before
and with gopros and going underwater with

651.57.text:
the gopro cameras we can now actually film
them underwater so we can actually see if

655.57.text:
the behaviours beneath the surface have changed
at all and our evidence so far is no nothing

662.55.text:
And with the tags, do they eventually drop
off? or do they

668.39.text:
Yep so if you think about the earring post
analogy again, you don't have something on

672.71.text:
the other end of it holding it in place, you
don't have a clasp holding it in place, the

676.96.text:
same as our body would kind of work it out
of eject the foreign object the same thing

682.39.text:
happens with the satellite transmitter tags,
it's kind of like a splinter, you've goa splinter

685.92.text:
in your skin and it might annoy you for a
little while but eventually your body oushes

689.54.text:
it back out and it falls out so that thats
what happens with these satellite transmitter

694.74.text:
tags, Alex is involved in a multi-year long
study in the Gulf of Maine where they've deployed

700.13.text:
tens of tags, of transmitter tags on humpback
whales off the waters of New England and they've

707.37.text:
gone out as many days as they can if not every
day for the last several years and they, they've

712.53.text:
monitored how the whales skin has responded,
has it swelled up, it doesn't always swell

717.12.text:
up what happens with the healing process,
how long does it take for the whale to kind

722.66.text:
of reject the satellite transmitter and then
once the transmitter's gone what's left? could

728.12.text:
you actually see the scar if you will from
where the transmitter was removed so we're

733.98.text:
learning more and more about how the whales
do that.

736.58.text:
But yes, they will fall off
Yep, okay, and how often do you check these

742.62.text:
I check 'em as often as I can and at least
twice a day, it's the kind of thing where

748.23.text:
we pre-program the transmitter tags in advance
so that requires a little bit of scientific

754.42.text:
analysis in the lead up and Alex was kind
enough to teach me how to do that this year,

758.59.text:
it's it was fantastic, I learned so much about
how the satellites work and how the transmitters

763.13.text:
work so when they're transmitting I'm online
checking them, even between my lectures at

770.03.text:
the University of Canterbury I'll run back
to my office and say ok, is that one still

773.83.text:
there or did it start moving, you know it's
really exciting, it's hour by hour

777.53.text:
So you mention that you've got seven migrating
whales, but you've launched nine, what's happended

784.02.text:
to the, do you know what's happended to the
other two?

785.46.text:
Yeah, so , so one of them, we launched it
and it was headed for a perfect deployment

791.80.text:
and a whale, a whale, a wave, uh, a whitecap
broke just before the transmitter tag was

798.90.text:
going to get deployed and the god new on this
one is that it actualy the wave defelcte it

804.07.text:
so that it didn't hit the whale we can see
in the video footage that the transmitter

tag basically hit the wave and went spiralling
off so it's on the borttom if the ocean so

812.96.text:
that one was never actually deployed
unretreivable

815.07.text:
yeah, well it's forty six metres of water,
they don't have a decompression tank in Rarotonga

819.70.text:
so it's just a little bit deep to try to retrieve
so if somebody could get a decompression tank

823.96.text:
it could save a few thousand dollars and eventually
recover it

827.41.text:
and the other one, it more than likely, the
camera footage we have of that one's deployment

835.25.text:
it didn't go in all of the way so it was it
was kind of like the earring was sticking,

839.17.text:
just went in a little bit and the majority
of the earring was sticking out of the body

842.75.text:
so in that the movement through the water
more than likely pulled it back out again

849.89.text:
so it lasted for about a day and a half, we
still got some interesting results off it

854.80.text:
but it only lasted a day and a half, all the
other ones are still going, it's just great

858.55.text:
So what has been, what was your most memorable
moment from your time in Rarotonga this year?

864.12.text:
Yeah, um, I have so many but the, the most
memorable moment was probably seeing a week

869.96.text:
old newborn a baby, so this is what they do
in Rarotonga the mothers, the pregnant um,

876.06.text:
females come to give birth and the males show
up to help create the next generation so they're

882.04.text:
breeding and giving birth in the tropical
waters they don't feed in the tropical waters

886.44.text:
but the most memorable thing was seeing this
you know, ten foot long pure white underbelly

894.22.text:
just hanging out at the surface of the water
slapping his pectoral fins, he's basically

898.58.text:
just splashing around in his bathtub, he was
doing it on his back you know his nose was

903.96.text:
underwater he was just having a good old time
just splashing around it was really neat to

908.46.text:
see that behaviour, so that's my most memorable
moment

912.13.text:
I also hear that you were the chief photographer
as well

915.64.text:
Ah, everybody had a camera, we're trying to
collect as much data as possible so gopros

921.70.text:
on the helmets, we wear the helmets for the
health and safety reasons and you know the

925.75.text:
helmet also gives you a nice stable platform
to deploy a gopro, you've got a camera in

929.89.text:
your hands and a gopro on your helmet and
Abigail's in the back with the gopro on the

933.87.text:
floating wand so we can put it under the water,
Nan has her SLR camera taking with a telephoto

940.70.text:
taking really high resolution pictures of
the dorsal fines and the flukes and there's

944.69.text:
a support boat, the support boat is doing
lots of things, one of the things they're

949.85.text:
doing is recording the acoustics and the songs
and the vocalisations that the whales have,

954.46.text:
from a distance away so we've got skin samples
from them as well, the support boat would

959.08.text:
come in and pick up some skin samples from
just kind of sloughing off of the skin when

962.54.text:
the whales surface we getting not just the
tracking data but we're getting DNA data from

967.69.text:
the skin, we'll have acoustic data from the
song, we'll have the video footage, the dorsal

972.51.text:
fin images, the fluke images, we'll try to
integrate all that data into one consistent

978.87.text:
So it's really more than just tracking whales,
you're getting a whole other bunch of information

982.55.text:
as well
Yeah, yeah, Nan does all of those other things

984.91.text:
every year, she's been doing this, that fundamental
whale ecology data colelction for seventeen

992.33.text:
years and she's winning a lifetime achievement
award in New York city in October and it's

999.13.text:
one of the greatest data sets for any cetation
population on the plant, yes, this is one

1006.24.text:
of the reasons why we go to Rarotonga to tag,
it's because we have such a good platform

1009.65.text:
from Nan's work over many years to say Alright,
she knows these whales, we understand their

1014.51.text:
lineage, we understand their basic behaviours
let's go and study them with respect to their

1019.72.text:
movements, it's the perfect place to do tagging
So there are approximately only five thousand

1025.26.text:
humpback whales dispersed across Oceania and
Oceania humpback whales as a whole aren't

1030.74.text:
recovering as quickly as other populations,
what's your advice for our viewers who may

1036.19.text: want to help preserve these whales?

1038.54.text:
Yes, there's probably two things, um, that
people can do, one is just become more aware,

1045.64.text:
it's really easy for us to be sitting here
in Wellington in being on land and just doing

1049.81.text:
regualr all day to day human things, these
whales are out there 24/7 365 in the ocean,

1056.41.text:
so the rubbish that's blowing down thr street
can actually get into the ocean and that plastic

1063.25.text:
bag looks a lot like a squid so some whales
eat squid or jellyfish, for example, Nan has

1069.72.text:
actually found dead whales washed up on the
beach in Rarotonga and she'd the nurse so

1075.75.text:
she actually does the necropsy on the dead
whale it's not uncommon to find plastic bags

1082.96.text:
in the stomachs of some of the whales so that
it's being more aware of what we're doing,

1088.29.text:
it might be out-of-sight, out-of-mind, just
that kind of general awareness and understanding

1093.09.text:
of what we do on land can have an impact in
the ocean is one thing, the other is you know

1097.30.text:
for people who are interested in supporting
the research, we do this on a shoestring,

1100.68.text:
you know to be honest, and Nan has saved up
seven years to have the money to buy these

1106.03.text:
tags and a lot of it is her own money, and
there are ways to make donations through whaleresearch.org,

1112.87.text:
that's Nan's foundation, um, so there are
ways to support the research financially as

1119.39.text:
Ok, so before we wrap up, if you could say
one thing about a humpback whale what would

1128.41.text:
Oh, goodness, one thing about humpback whales,
they're emotional, that was another one of

1136.05.text:
the things that I really, they're, the joy
of the baby whales splashing around in the

1140.56.text:
water, you know the anxiety of the mother
who didn't want us to be that close to her

1145.42.text:
baby, you know you could see that she was
being protective of the baby so we stayed

1150.75.text:
away and used the telephoto lens to take pictures
and didn't try to put any tags on either if

1156.43.text:
them, um, they have emotions, the young sub-adult
males that would just hang out with us for

1162.44.text:
hours, turn the engine off, eat lunch and
there are whales just hanging out, you can

1168.06.text:
look over the side, you seethe white of the
underbelly, you know that they're on their

1171.37.text:
side looking up at you
They're just as curious about us as we are

1174.82.text:
about them and all these things you know tell
me that there's a lot going on upstairs in

1178.81.text:
whales, in part of that is that they're emotional
and they do feel things the same way we feel.

Thank you very much for talking to us today

we're eagerly awaiting to see how far the
